column1: Will the Conservative Party hold a vote of no confidence in Boris Johnson in 2022?
column4: Yes, but it will not pass
column5: ['Yes, and it will pass', 'Yes, but it will not pass', 'No']
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Non-US Politics']
Anne, it's finished - it did happen but it did not pass; the question will be resolved in any minute now:
Not that it will count.... Boris manages to survive once more - Would think the question can close now
Polling experts I trust like the New Statesman's Harry Lambert are calling for him to survive this vote but emerge fatally wounded.
MPs seem to consistently think he'll win, so I'm reducing, but I think the logic for individual MPs still leaves room for a "surprise"
No reason for me to update before the vote but I'll put this in now in hopes I don't need to update later

Rationale: My gut feeling is that because this is going for a no-vote that this will be more likely than not in a bin 1 resolution. However, I do not trust my analysis on historical no-confidence / confidence votes in the UK. Because of this, I lean into the current crowd guidance, and I expect it to continue to drop.
If all the MPs think/know it'll be close and will damage his leadership further, they might as well kick him out now, rather than prolong it. Best to be rid of him than tarnish the Party further.

I think it's more likely than the crowd, now I've considered what this choice will feel like to the MPs casting their ballots. They will have heard the discontent over the jubilee weekend, they will have seen the royalists boo him, they know their seats will be at risk, they know this story will not be buried and they'll have to keep on defending him. I think they haven't got confidence in him and they will know they need to replace him before the next election.
Early signs today are that Tory MPs still haven't found their moral compass
There's probably not much point in updating this since the question will resolve today before forecasts issued today are 'counted'. That said, I'd written the below before I realised that.

Sir Graham Brady, chairman of the 1922 Committee, said in a statement Monday that the number of Conservative Party parliamentarians calling for the vote had reached the necessary threshold. The vote will be held between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. local time on Monday.
Graham Brady says there will be a vote this evening

Looks like they are going ahead with it and he should be able to dodge this one because its more a case of wanting a scapegoat but transversely there is not much option in the way of putting someone else in just yet and the feeling might well be he could do a better job trying to make up for things. This would be round one, either way the question closes if there is a vote and another question might pop up a little while latter, round two might be very different. Boris by the way was the one that put an end to drinking on the trains in London, used to be nice to buy some beers on the way home and have a quiet drink as you made your way back
Dä Sultan - I Love it, The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam meets Forest Gump :)
Obv no longer a forecast on whether it will happen. Huge payroll vote but…

With a Murdoch paper like the Times calling that enough letters have arrived at the 1922 committee to force a vote then it is getting hard to see Johnson dodging this bullet. However, the question remains: if he lost would he resign?
https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/uk-officials-expect-johnson-leadership-challenge-this-week-times-2022-06-05/
Going back to 50/50 on bins 1 and 2 as the results of by-elections on June 23 may be in favour of bin 1, if the no confidence vote has not already happened by then.
Peer betting exchange platforms have this at around 75%, massive divergence compared to crowd consensus. I will meet halfway.
My own view is still that if he knows with certainty he will lose a vote, he will just resign. But a vote could easily happen.

Boris has lost all credibility. He is loathed by the public and epitomises all that is wrong with the uk. His ridiculous excuses for the behaviour he oversaw at party gate and his own behaviour would not wash in any other job. He has no respect, nor do many of his cabinet.
Crowd too high imo. If Tories lose by elections next month this looks likely.

According to the Guardian and the Independent, there is an increase in Tory MPs calling for a change of leadership. This forecast accounts for an increased possibility of a vote being called by or at the restart of parliament.
Updating following rumours that the threshold has been met...
My forecasts on this one have been so noisy. I think following the news on this topic has actually been counterproductive.
Updating following end of police investigation into partygate and local elections.

Adjusting following election results but they haven't really changed my thinking - plenty of disquiet (including in London boroughs where many staffers and MPs will live), Johnson's performance is worse than Theresa May's. Will they feel more confident following Starmer's insipid showing or the increased prospect of a covid fine?

Tory MPs will be worried about replacing Boris as he is still their main hope of retaining the gains they made in the red wall. The only possible future leader who could hold those seats might be Ben Wallace. If he makes a move then this forecast will change.
"Boris Johnson to face inquiry into claims he misled parliament over Partygate as MPs pass vote"

Increasing likelihood because of whips’ nervousness ahead of commons vote and expectation of more fines. Fundamentally, there remains few alternatives and the timing isn’t easy (war, economic crisis, etc).
I don't know how he does it, but BoJo tells a tale like no other
Even less appetite now amongst Conservative MPs for a leadership election. Sunak is damaged and there is no other generally accepted candidate. Ben Wallace, perhaps.
Following the example of the American cousins, the Tories have all reported to surgery for spine removal.
Increased likelihood following reception of fines and prospect of Sunak resigning and with this fine at least part of his reasoning.

Updated to reflect: - news of fine (for at least one party) on Boris Johnson - that the police found that he attended the party much longer than he had said - calls for recall of Parliament - expectation that this will further weaken local elections results (in combination with the Chancellor's new reputational problems and the underwhelming Spring Statement). However, still overwhelmingly expect Tory MPs to resist changing leader in the absence of other compelling options, or while there are so many difficult things to yet navigate.
A lot of time left but going off the fact that it seems rare for a public figure to be ousted during wartime and replaced. A 1 in 10 chance is still a big chance.
Business as usual.
off the agenda now due to ukraine, the knives will be out again later in the year and they'll get the required number of letters but it won't pass because there is no viable alternative PM.

The attention is elsewhere now. Although I am inclined to think that it depends on the resolution to the conflict, with the West looking unfavorably to Russia; those that have a legacy with the oligarchs may pay a price, Johnson is one of them, but not the only one in EU that have the pockets lined with Russian money (ehm, ... not rubles of course)
Moving substantially toward no. I'm curious to see though if attention returns to this if attention on the Russian invasion lessens this year.

Still suspect mostly no, although I have upped the possibility of it passing (from 4 to 6) as I think the inflation costs over the next few months are going to be really quite something in terms of Govt unpopularity (translated through backbenchers).

Baseline: - Aggregation of various prediction markets have Boris to still be PM in 2022 at around 66%-75%. This feels a little low based on current evidence so I feel 80% is more appropriate. Meaning in some way there is a 20% chance he will cease to be PM in 2022 (The most likely way is from a No confidence vote).

Again, hardly following the British day to day politics. But the Ukraine war is now the attention focus. And there is not much what Boris Johnson can do, or to say not much, he can screw up. But if is facing again pressure he might also point that British intelligence seemed to grasp quite accurately the development in Russia which led to the invasion of Ukraine. So he propably would sell this and the arms deliveries to Ukraine as success of his leadership to rally support for himself and that is not a good idea to replace him in such an international crisis. So please feel free to let me know what did get wrong or I've missed! Thanks.

The invasion of Ukraine has dulled the impact of Partygate. When the Metropolitan Police report and the full Sue Gray investigation is released there will be more pressure and members may seek to send letters, likewise if the Conservatives return poor results in the May local elections, or lose flagship councils like Wandsworth (where Johnson ally Lord Lister was leader.) The fact remains that there may be Conservatives who have withdrawn letters since the height of Partygate in May. There's a chance that a few letters may tip the balance over the requisite number after the above three moments in time. I think however, there is a marginally greater possibility that there will be a significant groundswell of opposition should things in Ukraine turn more sour, combined with party fallout, which means that if there is a vote of no-confidence, the Prime Minister is more likely to lose than win. On the whole, though, the greater likelihood is that if Ukraine persists, Johnson will survive 2022.

"Sir Keir Starmer said: "Look, at the moment the prime minister is obviously concentrating on the job in hand and we stand united as the United Kingdom on that issue." The party claimed later they were not technically withdrawing their demand for him to go, but without doubt, this crisis has fundamentally changed the opposition and the government's priorities." - BBC

Though the focus is on international issues currently, domestic politics has a way of returning with a bang. I expect the outcome of the council elections and the police inquiry to be two major moments which may decide this. I believe the international context means it is unlikely the Conservatives will seek to remove Boris, unless there is a dramatic change of narrative/position in either of the two events above, but I still think a negative council election or police inquiry report could mean an "accidental" vote of no confidence simply due to enough letters having been sent. I therefore think there is a 50% chance of a confidence vote, but only 10% chance that it would pass if called.
https://www.conservativehome.com/thetorydiary/2022/02/meanwhile-a-vote-of-confidence-in-johnsons-leadership-is-off-for-as-long-as-this-crisis-lasts.html

1/3: revised due to war - don’t think it’s likely there will be previous type of bungling of a confidence vote. If they do it, it will be on purpose at the moment as the stakes are high. 20/2: Revised due to 1) prospect of conflict in Ukraine, 2) that the reportedly 300 photos of parties are now less likely to be released, 3) conflict or risk of it will reduce stories of partygate and people likely to be more supportive of national govt during local elections.
UKraine is more important, Partygate is old news

This is a interesting question, due to the invasion of Ukraine which has resulted in significant sanctions that will effect the populace of Britain, i doubt anyone will want to remove Johnson. Who ever is in charge during the next 8 months will unfortunately care the blame for the outcome of these difficult sanctions. I think the Conservative Party is just fine with letting their “party” boy carry that burden.

Extremely difficult to see how he survives the May elections without getting to 55 letters. Whether he wins or not will depend a lot on potential challengers; Sunak potentially receiving a fine too could save Johnson
Currently, the UK is focused on Ukraine and Johnson is not only an excellent speaker but a persuasive. So we can expect a rally to flag scenario, at least for the short term.
Dodged that bullet, for now...
See https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1402111

Good reception from Conservative MPs to the Prime Minister yesterday when he announced the end of Covid regulations. As normality resumes, the tension over the lockdown parties may lessen in its salience, especially against the backdrop of potential war on the continent.
Adjusting back down after news on this has seemed fairly quiet recently.
Situation seems to be easing down. Lack of precedent and activity about the matter sugest that there might not be a vote of no confidence unless new scandals arise.
If Russia Invade UK Johnson save his position

20/2: Revised due to 1) prospect of conflict in Ukraine, 2) that the reportedly 300 photos of parties are now less likely to be released, 3) conflict or risk of it will reduce stories of partygate and people likely to be more supportive of national govt during local elections.
I think its unlikely that there will be no consequence, however it is a possibility.
I think that inflation plus his high propensity to do stupid things will lead to a no confidence vote
I still think Boris Johnson is managing the overall situation well, Conservative might not think it's worth to replace him

MPs are on a short recess and as the guardian said, have "tucked their letter-writing pens into their back pockets". News cycle has ben very favourable. The only way it could be better is if Russia invades Ukraine the day after the Met Police release their findings. I have increased my No by a bit.
Thinking it over and I have to think no vote at all, or resignation if a vote if guaranteed to pass, make "Yes and Pass" pretty unlikely.
As @Marthature said, "If you shoot at a king, don't miss." LOL. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1396784

1) The threshold for a vote is quite low. 2) There are sufficient events (investigation outcomes, local elections, Cummings' vendetta) in the next 10 months that could convince nervous colleagues to seek a new leader. 3) Previous career history, suggests Johnson is fired rather than quitting. 4) But, under May, we saw members trigger a vote before they were organised. 5) Whereas there are suggestions that Johnson's team will have some warning because Sir Graham Brady gives people the opportunity to withdraw letters (and some of Johnson's team have reportedly put some in). 6) Everyone has their own personal rubicon, and we've seen a number of associates pull away. Lots of them - the majority - have decided to to outsource their judgment to the police, Sue Gray, etc. rather than act on the facts of the case that have been already understood. 7) However, it's the group dynamics that will tell and they will move "slowly, and then suddenly" and I can't predict them!!

As the Conservative party support remains at 33% (against over 40% Labour) and Boris Johnson's ratings are below 30% (lowest ever) the Conservatives will need to send a strong signal to the electorate. Difficult to say whether it will pass. https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/united-kingdom/

I'm not particularly following the situation in the UK, but at the moment it seems to me Boris Johnson just has to wait it out that the querrels die down. It will take some time, and as long he is screwing up something else and/or some other scandal from his past is breaking the news. That seems to me the biggest risks at the moment for Boris Johnson, and these are in my estimate really hard to predict. A new scandal from his past, not unreasonable to expect, and if it happen than it has to be something of quite an order of magnitute (as an example, I thinking about something like Prince Andrew in cahoots with Jeffrey Epstein). To be clear, this is only a comparison for the sole purpose of illustrating my thoughts of what, in my estimation, would be big enough to bring down the current prime minister. And as long Boris Johnson is sitting the current affairs out, he will also get more scandal proof, because the people working for him and resigning are going to be replaced by more loyal ones. It also seems at the moment the tories don't have a clear alternative to replace him, at least nobody so far who can rally enough support. Please feel free to comment on my thoughts and what I have not taken into consideration.

"If you shoot at the king, don't miss," My sense of the Tories is that 1) their leaders, such as they are, know this; 2) the Tories don't have a consensus, and don't have an alternative leader in mind; 3) on the brink of war in the midst of a pandemic and an economic disaster is not a good time to change leaders. It weakens the people's unity even further, it makes the economy worse, and it annoys the bankers.
With the current state of the UK, and other global issues, nobody wants the job of PM; because of this, even if the Conservatives hold a vote of no confidence, it will not pass.
Teflon
A big thank you to @kevins for explaining the two types of no confidence votes... that was very helpful!
https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/feb/10/john-major-says-boris-johnson-broke-lockdown-laws-and-is-creating-mistrust
A vote will be called by a part of Tory MPs for public display, but there will be not enough votes for it to pass.

I think it will be in late 2022 with pressure mounting and jostling amongst potential successors. If he gets some kind of distracting event (say Ukraine) then he might get a reprieve for a bit hence a relatively high “no”

It seems that everyone has accepted that Bojo's ship is sinking. The question seems to be if he'll jump off it (if he'll resign) , if it'll get scuttled (if he'll be ousted in a vote of No Confidence), or if it'll get towed into the harbor (if he'll be allowed to serve until the next general election).
Clownish activities will catch up with BoJo.

Boris Johnson is mired in scandals and not just the ones centered around COVID. Now that the UK has Brexited, the one thing had going for him and the party, definitive resolution, is effectively spent and they now have to deal with the consequences. But while an excellent speaker he doesn't seem up to the task of managing conflict, avoiding new scandals, or charting cogent new path forward.

Based on what I have seen on BBC news as well as other news outlets the UK seems Boris Johnson has offered too little too late. Boris Johnson says he has learned and will do better but too many bad choices shows he must be a very slow learner!
Drunkards stay focused!
This may be delayed until may 2022 or even later as there are local elections elicit response from mps who may then be concernd about their own seats .
I’m afraid BJ will do something else stupid, that’s all he did. People do not change.

The failure of US Congress to successfully impeach President Trump is one of my primary measures of political outcomes in the 2020s. Publics (and increasingly political parties) appear to be drawn more to entertainers than to decision-makers and in that regard outcomes for Trump are a reasonable indication of outcomes for Johnson.
Johnson has escaped his critics often in the past. The recent events will fade somewhat and there doesn’t seem to be a popular contender to replace him.

Poor polling and further details of the party scandal and the Sue Gray report will tip this issue. There is an undercurrent of incompetence now cementing around him. Tory party will finally move to ditch him and repair the damage in the time ahead of the next election.
because conservatives in GB are standing right behind their leaders also if they're making mistakes
The momentum is already moving in this direction.
A vote of no confidence is unlikely, since memories will fade as the pandemic does. There will only be a vote if its organizers feel certain that it will pass.
Boris John will find a way to get around that
It's an excuse to get past the embarrassment of BoJo and the others facing a general election. He's doomed.

There is reason to believe that the minimum needed members necessary to hold a vote exist. It is not likely that the needed votes of the party MPs will be sufficient for a no confidence resolution. I do believe, however, that PM Johnson will accept the fact that he no longer should be the head of government and will find a way to leave the job of PM. Perhaps thinking of a later come back. It would please him greatly if the party rejecting him later had to return to ask him to lead them in the next election. That may not happen but his ego certainly would enjoy imagining such an event.

He's about 60/40 to go before the Nasty Party conference in Oct 2022 according to betting markets. Think he has a slightly stronger chance of hanging on than that. But, already quite a few of the 54 letters are in and the backstabbers are lining up (as ever with the Tories) so think he probably will face a vote in 2022. Most likely after they have had a disaster in May elections. If they do have a no confidence vote, I still think he is more likely to survive it than not.

Warning - this is a purely gut prediction. I think that the Conservative Party is not under any major pressure from opposition parties (Labour) at the moment and thus would not need to make a show of distancing itself from Johnson in this manner. While the scandal paints Johnson in a poor light, is not out of keeping with the persona that made him oddly popular in the first place. Thus, it will not alienate diehard supporters nor convert new critics.

Bringing this forecast in line with my forecast about if Boris will cease to be PM before 6/23. PMs can count. This vote won't be brought until it will pass it because the last thing that those who will call it want is to give Boris a pass for a year.

I think the chances he's out are around 75%, but there's a decent chance that he survives the vote of no confidence and steps down anyway due to a large number turning against him, and also that he steps down before a vote of no confidence is actually held.

update with respect to greater short-term likelihood of a vote (mail hostile, question that Johnson no longer is able to lead just because of the amount of no confidence so far): the overall probability this year does still not go up by much
it time
Two mechnisms of exit for Johnson if he is to stop being PM. He can resign (this would resolve as 'No', or 'Yes, but it will not pass') or he can be ousted ('Yes, and it will pass').

I'm unclear on the parliamentary rules... I'm reading on wikipedia that the no confidence motion is one of two ways an early election can occur. The Conservative party holds 359/650 seats in the House of Commons. Would they need to have a vote of no confidence to select a new Prime Minister? 15% of Conservative Party members is 54 Conservative MPs that would have to submit a letter to the "1922 Committee" to trigger a vote. I understand that people are fed up with Boris Johnson over the garden parties, but that still seems a high number of MPs required to trigger a no confidence vote.

There are multiple factors in play here - When will the Sue Gray report be published/ police investigation be completed (will it be before or after the May local elections) Suppose it is published after the May Local Elections, that just makes the case for a no confidence motion being passed more compelling. (Assuming both the Election results and Sue Gray report are really unfavorable for BJ) Suppose some conservatives jump the gun and call for a No confidence motion earlier, there is a real chance that it doesn`t go through and BJ stays in power. Either ways if BJ has to go, he will have to be removed, he doesnt quite strike me as the type who would voluntarily resign. https://edition.cnn.com/2022/02/05/uk/boris-johnson-leadership-scandals-intl-cmd-gbr/index.html https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/boris-johnson-tory-leadership-letters-b2007823.html

Most likely a vote of no confidence will not occur before the results of the local elections in May. After that Johnson can be used to deflect blame from the Conservative party for the government's mishandling of the UK. However, the current front-runners will not be to the English electorate's taste. I will revisit this question then.

Estimates of between 30 and 45 of the required 54 have been submitted or are pending though many of these seem to be 'remain' MPs that are pretty anti BJ since Brexit. Not that it matters who submits them. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/feb/05/partygate-johnsons-removal-is-now-inevitable-warns-loyalist?CMP=Share_AndroidApp_Other So starting with will they get enough MPs, I give it an 80% chance. Passed no-confidence votes are pretty rare (assuming this is a proper government no confidence vote, possibly not) https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motions_of_no_confidence_in_the_United_Kingdom#:~:text=Under%20the%20Act%2C%20if%20a,a%20general%20election%20is%20held. Once we have the numbers I give another 20% chance that BJ would resign before the vote, hence no vote takes place. This number comes off the "yes and it will pass" outcome only because if BJs whips say that they don't have the numbers to win then he might as well leave without the shame of a vote. For the remaining 60% of my forecast I wonder who would be leader in the resulting leadership challenge. When we forecast the Sunak chancellor of the exchequer question a few said he would only leave if he either became prime minister (BJ leaves) or gets demoted (BJ fires him). Presumably he could be part of this shuffle, but seeing as he was drinking beers with Boris at his birthday he will probably lay low for a while. There are also claims that most MPs are still behind Boris. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/feb/05/nadine-dorries-claims-vast-majority-of-tories-behind-boris-johnson?CMP=Share_AndroidApp_Other Quite a hard one. And I have talked myself down quite a lot from my first impressions

I was previously answering the question, "If Boris Johnson were to go, how likely is a no confidence vote to pass?" The question makes it easy to assume he is leaving and that a no confidence vote is the primary way to leave office, which if it were, it's certainly not the only way out. I also considered the question in my previous rationale, which was, "How many No Confidence votes have passed versus how many Prime Ministers just simply resigned?"

Lining up with my other forecast: I split this up as 30% short term from partygate revelations, 30% due to May elections, and then the main flashpoints will have passed but his party still wants him out before the next election.
How many No Confidence votes have passed versus how many Prime Ministers just simply resigned?
as @MrLittleTexas points out, if Boris resigned there'd not be a no-confidence vote taken on him.
another member of his team resigned today

Initial forecast. I'm currently at 100% on Boris leaving before the 23rd of June (https://www.gjopen.com/questions/2233-before-23-june-2022-will-boris-johnson-cease-to-be-prime-minister-of-the-united-kingdom) so I'm primarily treating this question as a question about how Boris will leave. I don't expect Boris to resign of his own will, so 75% on him losing a vote of no confidence that I think he could lose as long as Tories can think of a viable successor i.e., if Sunak, Truss or some other Tory makes a case to their colleagues (as they have presumably been doing in the background). 20% he manages to survive a vote of no confidence, but does not do so with a comfortable enough majority and resigns whe thinks get even worse e.g., after big losses in the May elections. 5% on him not facing a vote of no confidence e.g., if he resigns after the May elections before being forced out by a vote of no confidence.
